tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter I. Down the Rabbit-Hole
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, ‘and what is the use of a book,’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: thought Alice ‘without pictures or conversations?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was nothing so VERY remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so VERY much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself, ‘Oh dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I shall be late!’ (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually TOOK A WATCH OUT OF ITS WAISTCOAT-POCKET, and looked at it, and then hurried on,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hole under the hedge.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Either the well was very deep, or she fell very slowly, for she had plenty of time as she went down to look about her and to wonder what was going to happen next.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: First, she tried to look down and make out what she was coming to, but it was too dark to see anything; then she looked at the sides of the well, and noticed that they were filled with cupboards and book-shelves; here and there she saw maps and pictures hung upon pegs.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She took down a jar from one of the shelves as she passed; it was labelled ‘ORANGE MARMALADE’, but to her great disappointment it was empty: she did not like to drop the jar for fear of killing somebody, so managed to put it into one of the cupboards as she fell past it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well!’ thought Alice to herself, ‘after such a fall as this, I shall think nothing of tumbling down stairs!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: How brave they’ll all think me at home!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Why, I wouldn’t say anything about it, even if I fell off the top of the house!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (Which was very likely true.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Down, down, down.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Would the fall NEVER come to an end!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wonder how many miles I’ve fallen by this time?’ she said aloud.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I must be getting somewhere near the centre of the earth.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Let me see: that would be four thousand miles down, I think—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ’ (for, you see, Alice had learnt several things of this sort in her lessons in the schoolroom, and though this was not a VERY good opportunity for showing off her knowledge, as there was no one to listen to her, still it was good practice to say it over) ‘—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: yes, that’s about the right distance—but then I wonder what Latitude or Longitude I’ve got to?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (Alice had no idea what Latitude was, or Longitude either, but thought they were nice grand words to say.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Presently she began again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wonder if I shall fall right THROUGH the earth!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: How funny it’ll seem to come out among the people that walk with their heads downward!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Antipathies, I think—’ (she was rather glad there WAS no one listening, this time, as it didn’t sound at all the right word) ‘—but I shall have to ask them what the name of the country is, you know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Please, Ma’am, is this New Zealand or Australia?’ (and she tried to curtsey as she spoke—fancy CURTSEYING as you’re falling through the air!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Do you think you could manage it?)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And what an ignorant little girl she’ll think me for asking!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: No, it’ll never do to ask: perhaps I shall see it written up somewhere.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Down, down, down.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was nothing else to do, so Alice soon began talking again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Dinah’ll miss me very much to-night, I should think!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (Dinah was the cat.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I hope they’ll remember her saucer of milk at tea-time.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Dinah my dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I wish you were down here with me!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There are no mice in the air, I’m afraid, but you might catch a bat, and that’s very like a mouse, you know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But do cats eat bats, I wonder?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And here Alice began to get rather sleepy, and went on saying to herself, in a dreamy sort of way, ‘Do cats eat bats?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Do cats eat bats?’ and sometimes, ‘Do bats eat cats?’ for, you see, as she couldn’t answer either question, it didn’t much matter which way she put it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She felt that she was dozing off, and had just begun to dream that she was walking hand in hand with Dinah, and saying to her very earnestly, ‘Now, Dinah, tell me the truth: did you ever eat a bat?’ when suddenly, thump! thump!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: down she came upon a heap of sticks and dry leaves, and the fall was over.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was not a bit hurt, and she jumped up on to her feet in a moment: she looked up, but it was all dark overhead; before her was another long passage, and the White Rabbit was still in sight, hurrying down it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was not a moment to be lost: away went Alice like the wind, and was just in time to hear it say, as it turned a corner, ‘Oh my ears and whiskers, how late it’s getting!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She was close behind it when she turned the corner, but the Rabbit was no longer to be seen: she found herself in a long, low hall, which was lit up by a row of lamps hanging from the roof.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There were doors all round the hall, but they were all locked; and when Alice had been all the way down one side and up the other, trying every door, she walked sadly down the middle, wondering how she was ever to get out again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Suddenly she came upon a little three-legged table, all made of solid glass; there was nothing on it except a tiny golden key, and Alice’s first thought was that it might belong to one of the doors of the hall; but, alas!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: either the locks were too large, or the key was too small, but at any rate it would not open any of them.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, on the second time round, she came upon a low curtain she had not noticed before, and behind it was a little door about fifteen inches high: she tried the little golden key in the lock, and to her great delight it fitted!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: How she longed to get out of that dark hall, and wander about among those beds of bright flowers and those cool fountains, but she could not even get her head through the doorway;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘and even if my head would go through,’ thought poor Alice, ‘it would be of very little use without my shoulders.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh, how I wish I could shut up like a telescope!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I think I could, if I only knew how to begin.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: For, you see, so many out-of-the-way things had happened lately, that Alice had begun to think that very few things indeed were really impossible.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There seemed to be no use in waiting by the little door, so she went back to the table, half hoping she might find another key on it, or at any rate a book of rules for shutting people up like telescopes:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: this time she found a little bottle on it, [‘which certainly was not here before,’ said Alice,) and round the neck of the bottle was a paper label, with the words ‘DRINK ME’ beautifully printed on it in large letters.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was all very well to say ‘Drink me,’ but the wise little Alice was not going to do THAT in a hurry.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, I’ll look first,’ she said, ‘and see whether it’s marked “poison” or not’; for she had read several nice little histories about children who had got burnt, and eaten up by wild beasts and other unpleasant things,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: all because they WOULD not remember the simple rules their friends had taught them: such as, that a red-hot poker will burn you if you hold it too long; and that if you cut your finger VERY deeply with a knife, it usually bleeds; and she had never forgotten that,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: if you drink much from a bottle marked ‘poison,’ it is almost certain to disagree with you, sooner or later.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, this bottle was NOT marked ‘poison,’ so Alice ventured to taste it, and finding it very nice, (it had, in fact, a sort of mixed flavour of cherry-tart, custard, pine-apple, roast turkey, toffee, and hot buttered toast,) she very soon finished it off.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And so it was indeed: she was now only ten inches high, and her face brightened up at the thought that she was now the right size for going through the little door into that lovely garden.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: First, however, she waited for a few minutes to see if she was going to shrink any further: she felt a little nervous about this; ‘for it might end, you know,’ said Alice to herself, ‘in my going out altogether, like a candle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I wonder what I should be like then?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she tried to fancy what the flame of a candle is like after the candle is blown out, for she could not remember ever having seen such a thing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: After a while, finding that nothing more happened, she decided on going into the garden at once; but, alas for poor Alice! when she got to the door, she found she had forgotten the little golden key, and when she went back to the table for it,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she found she could not possibly reach it: she could see it quite plainly through the glass, and she tried her best to climb up one of the legs of the table, but it was too slippery; and when she had tired herself out with trying, the poor little thing sat down and cried.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come, there’s no use in crying like that!’ said Alice to herself, rather sharply; ‘I advise you to leave off this minute!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She generally gave herself very good advice, (though she very seldom followed it), and sometimes she scolded herself so severely as to bring tears into her eyes;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and once she remembered trying to box her own ears for having cheated herself in a game of croquet she was playing against herself, for this curious child was very fond of pretending to be two people.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But it’s no use now,’ thought poor Alice, ‘to pretend to be two people!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Why, there’s hardly enough of me left to make ONE respectable person!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Soon her eye fell on a little glass box that was lying under the table: she opened it, and found in it a very small cake, on which the words ‘EAT ME’ were beautifully marked in currants.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, I’ll eat it,’ said Alice, ‘and if it makes me grow larger, I can reach the key; and if it makes me grow smaller, I can creep under the door; so either way I’ll get into the garden, and I don’t care which happens!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She ate a little bit, and said anxiously to herself, ‘Which way?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Which way?’, holding her hand on the top of her head to feel which way it was growing, and she was quite surprised to find that she remained the same size:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: to be sure, this generally happens when one eats cake, but Alice had got so much into the way of expecting nothing but out-of-the-way things to happen, that it seemed quite dull and stupid for life to go on in the common way.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she set to work, and very soon finished off the cake.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter II. The Pool of Tears
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Curiouser and curiouser!’ cried Alice (she was so much surprised, that for the moment she quite forgot how to speak good English); ‘now I’m opening out like the largest telescope that ever was!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Good-bye, feet!’ (for when she looked down at her feet, they seemed to be almost out of sight, they were getting so far off).
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, my poor little feet, I wonder who will put on your shoes and stockings for you now, dears?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’m sure _I_ shan’t be able!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I shall be a great deal too far off to trouble myself about you: you must manage the best way you can;—but I must be kind to them,’ thought Alice, ‘or perhaps they won’t walk the way I want to go!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Let me see: I’ll give them a new pair of boots every Christmas.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she went on planning to herself how she would manage it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They must go by the carrier,’ she thought; ‘and how funny it’ll seem, sending presents to one’s own feet!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And how odd the directions will look!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ALICE’S RIGHT FOOT, ESQ.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
HEARTHRUG,
  NEAR THE FENDER,
    (WITH ALICE’S LOVE).
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh dear, what nonsense I’m talking!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Just then her head struck against the roof of the hall: in fact she was now more than nine feet high, and she at once took up the little golden key and hurried off to the garden door.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Poor Alice!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was as much as she could do, lying down on one side, to look through into the garden with one eye; but to get through was more hopeless than ever: she sat down and began to cry again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You ought to be ashamed of yourself,’ said Alice, ‘a great girl like you,’ (she might well say this), ‘to go on crying in this way!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Stop this moment, I tell you!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But she went on all the same, shedding gallons of tears, until there was a large pool all round her, about four inches deep and reaching half down the hall.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: After a time she heard a little pattering of feet in the distance, and she hastily dried her eyes to see what was coming.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was the White Rabbit returning, splendidly dressed, with a pair of white kid gloves in one hand and a large fan in the other: he came trotting along in a great hurry, muttering to himself as he came, ‘Oh! the Duchess, the Duchess!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh! won’t she be savage if I’ve kept her waiting!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice felt so desperate that she was ready to ask help of any one;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: so, when the Rabbit came near her, she began, in a low, timid voice, ‘If you please, sir—’ The Rabbit started violently, dropped the white kid gloves and the fan, and skurried away into the darkness as hard as he could go.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice took up the fan and gloves, and, as the hall was very hot, she kept fanning herself all the time she went on talking: ‘Dear, dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: How queer everything is to-day!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And yesterday things went on just as usual.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I wonder if I’ve been changed in the night?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Let me think: was I the same when I got up this morning?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I almost think I can remember feeling a little different.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But if I’m not the same, the next question is, Who in the world am I?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Ah, THAT’S the great puzzle!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she began thinking over all the children she knew that were of the same age as herself, to see if she could have been changed for any of them.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m sure I’m not Ada,’ she said, ‘for her hair goes in such long ringlets, and mine doesn’t go in ringlets at all; and I’m sure I can’t be Mabel, for I know all sorts of things, and she, oh! she knows such a very little!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Besides, SHE’S she, and I’m I, and—oh dear, how puzzling it all is!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’ll try if I know all the things I used to know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Let me see: four times five is twelve, and four times six is thirteen, and four times seven is—oh dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I shall never get to twenty at that rate!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, the Multiplication Table doesn’t signify: let’s try Geography.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: London is the capital of Paris, and Paris is the capital of Rome, and Rome—no, THAT’S all wrong, I’m certain!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I must have been changed for Mabel!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’ll try and say “How doth the little—“’ and she crossed her hands on her lap as if she were saying lessons, and began to repeat it, but her voice sounded hoarse and strange, and the words did not come the same as they used to do:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘How doth the little crocodile
 Improve his shining tail,
And pour the waters of the Nile
 On every golden scale!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘How cheerfully he seems to grin,
 How neatly spread his claws,
And welcome little fishes in
 With gently smiling jaws!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m sure those are not the right words,’ said poor Alice, and her eyes filled with tears again as she went on, ‘I must be Mabel after all, and I shall have to go and live in that poky little house, and have next to no toys to play with, and oh! ever so many lessons to learn!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: No, I’ve made up my mind about it; if I’m Mabel, I’ll stay down here!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It’ll be no use their putting their heads down and saying “Come up again, dear!”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I shall only look up and say “Who am I then?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Tell me that first, and then, if I like being that person, I’ll come up: if not, I’ll stay down here till I’m somebody else”—but, oh dear!’ cried Alice, with a sudden burst of tears, ‘I do wish they WOULD put their heads down!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I am so VERY tired of being all alone here!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As she said this she looked down at her hands, and was surprised to see that she had put on one of the Rabbit’s little white kid gloves while she was talking.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How CAN I have done that?’ she thought.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I must be growing small again.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She got up and went to the table to measure herself by it, and found that, as nearly as she could guess, she was now about two feet high, and was going on shrinking rapidly:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she soon found out that the cause of this was the fan she was holding, and she dropped it hastily, just in time to avoid shrinking away altogether.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That WAS a narrow escape!’ said Alice, a good deal frightened at the sudden change, but very glad to find herself still in existence; ‘and now for the garden!’ and she ran with all speed back to the little door: but, alas!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: the little door was shut again, and the little golden key was lying on the glass table as before, ‘and things are worse than ever,’ thought the poor child, ‘for I never was so small as this before, never!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And I declare it’s too bad, that it is!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As she said these words her foot slipped, and in another moment, splash! she was up to her chin in salt water.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Her first idea was that she had somehow fallen into the sea, ‘and in that case I can go back by railway,’ she said to herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (Alice had been to the seaside once in her life, and had come to the general conclusion, that wherever you go to on the English coast you find a number of bathing machines in the sea, some children digging in the sand with wooden spades, then a row of lodging houses,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and behind them a railway station.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, she soon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wish I hadn’t cried so much!’ said Alice, as she swam about, trying to find her way out.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I shall be punished for it now, I suppose, by being drowned in my own tears!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: That WILL be a queer thing, to be sure!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, everything is queer to-day.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Just then she heard something splashing about in the pool a little way off, and she swam nearer to make out what it was:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: at first she thought it must be a walrus or hippopotamus, but then she remembered how small she was now, and she soon made out that it was only a mouse that had slipped in like herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Would it be of any use, now,’ thought Alice, ‘to speak to this mouse?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Everything is so out-of-the-way down here, that I should think very likely it can talk: at any rate, there’s no harm in trying.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she began: ‘O Mouse, do you know the way out of this pool?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I am very tired of swimming about here, O Mouse!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (Alice thought this must be the right way of speaking to a mouse: she had never done such a thing before, but she remembered having seen in her brother’s Latin Grammar, ‘A mouse—of a mouse—to a mouse—a mouse—O mouse!’)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mouse looked at her rather inquisitively, and seemed to her to wink with one of its little eyes, but it said nothing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Perhaps it doesn’t understand English,’ thought Alice; ‘I daresay it’s a French mouse, come over with William the Conqueror.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (For, with all her knowledge of history, Alice had no very clear notion how long ago anything had happened.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she began again: ‘Ou est ma chatte?’ which was the first sentence in her French lesson-book.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mouse gave a sudden leap out of the water, and seemed to quiver all over with fright.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, I beg your pardon!’ cried Alice hastily, afraid that she had hurt the poor animal’s feelings.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I quite forgot you didn’t like cats.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not like cats!’ cried the Mouse, in a shrill, passionate voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Would YOU like cats if you were me?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, perhaps not,’ said Alice in a soothing tone: ‘don’t be angry about it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And yet I wish I could show you our cat Dinah: I think you’d take a fancy to cats if you could only see her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She is such a dear quiet thing,’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice went on, half to herself, as she swam lazily about in the pool, ‘and she sits purring so nicely by the fire, licking her paws and washing her face—and she is such a nice soft thing to nurse—and she’s such a capital one for catching mice—oh, I beg your pardon!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: cried Alice again, for this time the Mouse was bristling all over, and she felt certain it must be really offended.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘We won’t talk about her any more if you’d rather not.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘We indeed!’ cried the Mouse, who was trembling down to the end of his tail.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘As if I would talk on such a subject!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Our family always HATED cats: nasty, low, vulgar things!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Don’t let me hear the name again!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I won’t indeed!’ said Alice, in a great hurry to change the subject of conversation.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Are you—are you fond—of—of dogs?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mouse did not answer, so Alice went on eagerly: ‘There is such a nice little dog near our house I should like to show you!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: A little bright-eyed terrier, you know, with oh, such long curly brown hair!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And it’ll fetch things when you throw them, and it’ll sit up and beg for its dinner, and all sorts of things—I can’t remember half of them—and it belongs to a farmer, you know, and he says it’s so useful, it’s worth a hundred pounds!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He says it kills all the rats and—oh dear!’ cried Alice in a sorrowful tone, ‘I’m afraid I’ve offended it again!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: For the Mouse was swimming away from her as hard as it could go, and making quite a commotion in the pool as it went.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she called softly after it, ‘Mouse dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Do come back again, and we won’t talk about cats or dogs either, if you don’t like them!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: When the Mouse heard this, it turned round and swam slowly back to her: its face was quite pale (with passion, Alice thought), and it said in a low trembling voice, ‘Let us get to the shore, and then I’ll tell you my history, and you’ll understand why it is I hate cats and dogs.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was high time to go, for the pool was getting quite crowded with the birds and animals that had fallen into it: there were a Duck and a Dodo, a Lory and an Eaglet, and several other curious creatures.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice led the way, and the whole party swam to the shore.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter III. A Caucus-Race and a Long Tale
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They were indeed a queer-looking party that assembled on the bank—the birds with draggled feathers, the animals with their fur clinging close to them, and all dripping wet, cross, and uncomfortable.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The first question of course was, how to get dry again: they had a consultation about this, and after a few minutes it seemed quite natural to Alice to find herself talking familiarly with them, as if she had known them all her life.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Indeed, she had quite a long argument with the Lory, who at last turned sulky, and would only say, ‘I am older than you, and must know better’;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and this Alice would not allow without knowing how old it was, and, as the Lory positively refused to tell its age, there was no more to be said.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: At last the Mouse, who seemed to be a person of authority among them, called out, ‘Sit down, all of you, and listen to me!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’LL soon make you dry enough!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They all sat down at once, in a large ring, with the Mouse in the middle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice kept her eyes anxiously fixed on it, for she felt sure she would catch a bad cold if she did not get dry very soon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Ahem!’ said the Mouse with an important air, ‘are you all ready?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This is the driest thing I know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Silence all round, if you please!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “William the Conqueror, whose cause was favoured by the pope, was soon submitted to by the English, who wanted leaders, and had been of late much accustomed to usurpation and conquest.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Edwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria—“’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Ugh!’ said the Lory, with a shiver.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I beg your pardon!’ said the Mouse, frowning, but very politely: ‘Did you speak?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not I!’ said the Lory hastily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I thought you did,’ said the Mouse.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—I proceed.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “Edwin and Morcar, the earls of Mercia and Northumbria, declared for him: and even Stigand, the patriotic archbishop of Canterbury, found it advisable—“’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Found WHAT?’ said the Duck.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Found IT,’ the Mouse replied rather crossly: ‘of course you know what “it” means.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I know what “it” means well enough, when I find a thing,’ said the Duck: ‘it’s generally a frog or a worm.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The question is, what did the archbishop find?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mouse did not notice this question, but hurriedly went on, ‘“—found it advisable to go with Edgar Atheling to meet William and offer him the crown.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: William’s conduct at first was moderate.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But the insolence of his Normans—” How are you getting on now, my dear?’ it continued, turning to Alice as it spoke.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘As wet as ever,’ said Alice in a melancholy tone: ‘it doesn’t seem to dry me at all.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘In that case,’ said the Dodo solemnly, rising to its feet, ‘I move that the meeting adjourn, for the immediate adoption of more energetic remedies—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Speak English!’ said the Eaglet.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t know the meaning of half those long words, and, what’s more, I don’t believe you do either!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And the Eaglet bent down its head to hide a smile: some of the other birds tittered audibly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What I was going to say,’ said the Dodo in an offended tone, ‘was, that the best thing to get us dry would be a Caucus-race.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What IS a Caucus-race?’ said Alice; not that she wanted much to know, but the Dodo had paused as if it thought that SOMEBODY ought to speak, and no one else seemed inclined to say anything.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why,’ said the Dodo, ‘the best way to explain it is to do it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (And, as you might like to try the thing yourself, some winter day, I will tell you how the Dodo managed it.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: First it marked out a race-course, in a sort of circle, [‘the exact shape doesn’t matter,’ it said,) and then all the party were placed along the course, here and there.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was no ‘One, two, three, and away,’ but they began running when they liked, and left off when they liked, so that it was not easy to know when the race was over.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, when they had been running half an hour or so, and were quite dry again, the Dodo suddenly called out ‘The race is over!’ and they all crowded round it, panting, and asking, ‘But who has won?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This question the Dodo could not answer without a great deal of thought, and it sat for a long time with one finger pressed upon its forehead (the position in which you usually see Shakespeare, in the pictures of him), while the rest waited in silence.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: At last the Dodo said, ‘EVERYBODY has won, and all must have prizes.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But who is to give the prizes?’ quite a chorus of voices asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why, SHE, of course,’ said the Dodo, pointing to Alice with one finger; and the whole party at once crowded round her, calling out in a confused way, ‘Prizes!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Prizes!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice had no idea what to do, and in despair she put her hand in her pocket, and pulled out a box of comfits, (luckily the salt water had not got into it), and handed them round as prizes.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was exactly one a-piece all round.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But she must have a prize herself, you know,’ said the Mouse.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course,’ the Dodo replied very gravely.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What else have you got in your pocket?’ he went on, turning to Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Only a thimble,’ said Alice sadly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Hand it over here,’ said the Dodo.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then they all crowded round her once more, while the Dodo solemnly presented the thimble, saying ‘We beg your acceptance of this elegant thimble’; and, when it had finished this short speech, they all cheered.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice thought the whole thing very absurd, but they all looked so grave that she did not dare to laugh; and, as she could not think of anything to say, she simply bowed, and took the thimble, looking as solemn as she could.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The next thing was to eat the comfits: this caused some noise and confusion, as the large birds complained that they could not taste theirs, and the small ones choked and had to be patted on the back.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, it was over at last, and they sat down again in a ring, and begged the Mouse to tell them something more.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You promised to tell me your history, you know,’ said Alice, ‘and why it is you hate—C and D,’ she added in a whisper, half afraid that it would be offended again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Mine is a long and a sad tale!’ said the Mouse, turning to Alice, and sighing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It IS a long tail, certainly,’ said Alice, looking down with wonder at the Mouse’s tail; ‘but why do you call it sad?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she kept on puzzling about it while the Mouse was speaking, so that her idea of the tale was something like this:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘Fury said to a
    mouse, That he
   met in the
  house,
“Let us
 both go to
  law: I will
   prosecute
    YOU.—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
Come,
           I’ll take no
           denial; We
          must have a
        trial: For
      really this
     morning I’ve
    nothing
    to do.”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
Said the
mouse to the
 cur, “Such
  a trial,
   dear Sir,
      With
    no jury
  or judge,
 would be
wasting
our
breath.”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
“I’ll be
judge, I’ll
 be jury,”
     Said
 cunning
  old Fury:
  “I’ll
  try the
    whole
    cause,
      and
   condemn
   you
  to
   death.”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You are not attending!’ said the Mouse to Alice severely.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What are you thinking of?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I beg your pardon,’ said Alice very humbly: ‘you had got to the fifth bend, I think?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I had NOT!’ cried the Mouse, sharply and very angrily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘A knot!’ said Alice, always ready to make herself useful, and looking anxiously about her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, do let me help to undo it!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I shall do nothing of the sort,’ said the Mouse, getting up and walking away.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You insult me by talking such nonsense!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I didn’t mean it!’ pleaded poor Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But you’re so easily offended, you know!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mouse only growled in reply.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Please come back and finish your story!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice called after it; and the others all joined in chorus, ‘Yes, please do!’ but the Mouse only shook its head impatiently, and walked a little quicker.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What a pity it wouldn’t stay!’ sighed the Lory, as soon as it was quite out of sight; and an old Crab took the opportunity of saying to her daughter ‘Ah, my dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Let this be a lesson to you never to lose YOUR temper!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Hold your tongue, Ma!’ said the young Crab, a little snappishly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’re enough to try the patience of an oyster!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wish I had our Dinah here, I know I do!’ said Alice aloud, addressing nobody in particular.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘She’d soon fetch it back!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And who is Dinah, if I might venture to ask the question?’ said the Lory.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice replied eagerly, for she was always ready to talk about her pet: ‘Dinah’s our cat.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she’s such a capital one for catching mice you can’t think!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And oh, I wish you could see her after the birds!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Why, she’ll eat a little bird as soon as look at it!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This speech caused a remarkable sensation among the party.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Some of the birds hurried off at once: one old Magpie began wrapping itself up very carefully, remarking, ‘I really must be getting home; the night-air doesn’t suit my throat!’ and a Canary called out in a trembling voice to its children, ‘Come away, my dears!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It’s high time you were all in bed!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: On various pretexts they all moved off, and Alice was soon left alone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wish I hadn’t mentioned Dinah!’ she said to herself in a melancholy tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nobody seems to like her, down here, and I’m sure she’s the best cat in the world!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh, my dear Dinah!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I wonder if I shall ever see you any more!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And here poor Alice began to cry again, for she felt very lonely and low-spirited.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: In a little while, however, she again heard a little pattering of footsteps in the distance, and she looked up eagerly, half hoping that the Mouse had changed his mind, and was coming back to finish his story.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter IV. The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something; and she heard it muttering to itself ‘The Duchess!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Duchess!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh my dear paws!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh my fur and whiskers!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She’ll get me executed, as sure as ferrets are ferrets!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Where CAN I have dropped them, I wonder?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice guessed in a moment that it was looking for the fan and the pair of white kid gloves, and she very good-naturedly began hunting about for them, but they were nowhere to be seen—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: everything seemed to have changed since her swim in the pool, and the great hall, with the glass table and the little door, had vanished completely.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Very soon the Rabbit noticed Alice, as she went hunting about, and called out to her in an angry tone, ‘Why, Mary Ann, what ARE you doing out here?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Run home this moment, and fetch me a pair of gloves and a fan!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Quick, now!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And Alice was so much frightened that she ran off at once in the direction it pointed to, without trying to explain the mistake it had made.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘He took me for his housemaid,’ she said to herself as she ran.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How surprised he’ll be when he finds out who I am!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But I’d better take him his fan and gloves—that is, if I can find them.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As she said this, she came upon a neat little house, on the door of which was a bright brass plate with the name ‘W.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: RABBIT’ engraved upon it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She went in without knocking, and hurried upstairs, in great fear lest she should meet the real Mary Ann, and be turned out of the house before she had found the fan and gloves.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How queer it seems,’ Alice said to herself, ‘to be going messages for a rabbit!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I suppose Dinah’ll be sending me on messages next!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she began fancying the sort of thing that would happen: ‘“Miss Alice!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Come here directly, and get ready for your walk!”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “Coming in a minute, nurse!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But I’ve got to see that the mouse doesn’t get out.”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Only I don’t think,’ Alice went on, ‘that they’d let Dinah stop in the house if it began ordering people about like that!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: By this time she had found her way into a tidy little room with a table in the window, and on it (as she had hoped)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: a fan and two or three pairs of tiny white kid gloves: she took up the fan and a pair of the gloves, and was just going to leave the room, when her eye fell upon a little bottle that stood near the looking-glass.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was no label this time with the words ‘DRINK ME,’ but nevertheless she uncorked it and put it to her lips.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I know SOMETHING interesting is sure to happen,’ she said to herself, ‘whenever I eat or drink anything; so I’ll just see what this bottle does.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I do hope it’ll make me grow large again, for really I’m quite tired of being such a tiny little thing!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It did so indeed, and much sooner than she had expected: before she had drunk half the bottle, she found her head pressing against the ceiling, and had to stoop to save her neck from being broken.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She hastily put down the bottle, saying to herself ‘That’s quite enough—I hope I shan’t grow any more—As it is, I can’t get out at the door—I do wish I hadn’t drunk quite so much!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alas! it was too late to wish that!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She went on growing, and growing, and very soon had to kneel down on the floor: in another minute there was not even room for this, and she tried the effect of lying down with one elbow against the door, and the other arm curled round her head.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Still she went on growing, and, as a last resource, she put one arm out of the window, and one foot up the chimney, and said to herself ‘Now I can do no more, whatever happens.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: What WILL become of me?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Luckily for Alice, the little magic bottle had now had its full effect, and she grew no larger: still it was very uncomfortable, and, as there seemed to be no sort of chance of her ever getting out of the room again, no wonder she felt unhappy.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It was much pleasanter at home,’ thought poor Alice, ‘when one wasn’t always growing larger and smaller, and being ordered about by mice and rabbits.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I almost wish I hadn’t gone down that rabbit-hole—and yet—and yet—it’s rather curious, you know, this sort of life!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I do wonder what CAN have happened to me!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: When I used to read fairy-tales, I fancied that kind of thing never happened, and now here I am in the middle of one!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There ought to be a book written about me, that there ought!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And when I grow up, I’ll write one—but I’m grown up now,’ she added in a sorrowful tone; ‘at least there’s no room to grow up any more HERE.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But then,’ thought Alice, ‘shall I NEVER get any older than I am now?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: That’ll be a comfort, one way—never to be an old woman—but then—always to have lessons to learn!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh, I shouldn’t like THAT!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, you foolish Alice!’ she answered herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How can you learn lessons in here?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Why, there’s hardly room for YOU, and no room at all for any lesson-books!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And so she went on, taking first one side and then the other, and making quite a conversation of it altogether; but after a few minutes she heard a voice outside, and stopped to listen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Mary Ann!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Mary Ann!’ said the voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Fetch me my gloves this moment!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then came a little pattering of feet on the stairs.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice knew it was the Rabbit coming to look for her, and she trembled till she shook the house, quite forgetting that she was now about a thousand times as large as the Rabbit, and had no reason to be afraid of it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Presently the Rabbit came up to the door, and tried to open it; but, as the door opened inwards, and Alice’s elbow was pressed hard against it, that attempt proved a failure.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice heard it say to itself ‘Then I’ll go round and get in at the window.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘THAT you won’t’ thought Alice, and, after waiting till she fancied she heard the Rabbit just under the window, she suddenly spread out her hand, and made a snatch in the air.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She did not get hold of anything, but she heard a little shriek and a fall, and a crash of broken glass, from which she concluded that it was just possible it had fallen into a cucumber-frame, or something of the sort.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Next came an angry voice—the Rabbit’s—‘ Pat!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Pat!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Where are you?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And then a voice she had never heard before, ‘Sure then I’m here!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Digging for apples, yer honour!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Digging for apples, indeed!’ said the Rabbit angrily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Here!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Come and help me out of THIS!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (Sounds of more broken glass.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Now tell me, Pat, what’s that in the window?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Sure, it’s an arm, yer honour!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (He pronounced it ‘arrum.’)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘An arm, you goose!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Who ever saw one that size?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Why, it fills the whole window!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Sure, it does, yer honour: but it’s an arm for all that.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, it’s got no business there, at any rate: go and take it away!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was a long silence after this, and Alice could only hear whispers now and then; such as, ‘Sure, I don’t like it, yer honour, at all, at all!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Do as I tell you, you coward!’ and at last she spread out her hand again, and made another snatch in the air.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This time there were TWO little shrieks, and more sounds of broken glass.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What a number of cucumber-frames there must be!’ thought Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wonder what they’ll do next!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As for pulling me out of the window, I only wish they COULD!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’m sure I don’t want to stay in here any longer!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She waited for some time without hearing anything more: at last came a rumbling of little cartwheels, and the sound of a good many voices all talking together: she made out the words: ‘Where’s the other ladder?—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Why, I hadn’t to bring but one; Bill’s got the other—Bill! fetch it here, lad!—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Here, put ‘em up at this corner—No, tie ‘em together first—they don’t reach half high enough yet—Oh! they’ll do well enough; don’t be particular—Here, Bill! catch hold of this rope—Will the roof bear?—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Mind that loose slate—Oh, it’s coming down!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Heads below!’ (a loud crash)—‘ Now, who did that?—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was Bill, I fancy—Who’s to go down the chimney?—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Nay, I shan’t!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: YOU do it!—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: That I won’t, then!—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Bill’s to go down—Here, Bill! the master says you’re to go down the chimney!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So Bill’s got to come down the chimney, has he?’ said Alice to herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Shy, they seem to put everything upon Bill!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I wouldn’t be in Bill’s place for a good deal: this fireplace is narrow, to be sure; but I THINK I can kick a little!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She drew her foot as far down the chimney as she could, and waited till she heard a little animal (she couldn’t guess of what sort it was) scratching and scrambling about in the chimney close above her: then, saying to herself ‘This is Bill,’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she gave one sharp kick, and waited to see what would happen next.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The first thing she heard was a general chorus of ‘There goes Bill!’ then the Rabbit’s voice along—‘ Catch him, you by the hedge!’ then silence, and then another confusion of voices—‘ Hold up his head—Brandy now—Don’t choke him—How was it, old fellow?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: What happened to you?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Tell us all about it!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Last came a little feeble, squeaking voice, [‘That’s Bill,’ thought Alice,) ‘Well, I hardly know—No more, thank ye; I’m better now—but I’m a deal too flustered to tell you—all I know is, something comes at me like a Jack-in-the-box, and up I goes like a sky-rocket!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘So you did, old fellow!’ said the others.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘We must burn the house down!’ said the Rabbit’s voice; and Alice called out as loud as she could, ‘If you do.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’ll set Dinah at you!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was a dead silence instantly, and Alice thought to herself, ‘I wonder what they WILL do next!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: If they had any sense, they’d take the roof off.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: After a minute or two, they began moving about again, and Alice heard the Rabbit say, ‘A barrowful will do, to begin with.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘A barrowful of WHAT?’ thought Alice; but she had not long to doubt, for the next moment a shower of little pebbles came rattling in at the window, and some of them hit her in the face.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ll put a stop to this,’ she said to herself, and shouted out, ‘You’d better not do that again!’ which produced another dead silence.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice noticed with some surprise that the pebbles were all turning into little cakes as they lay on the floor, and a bright idea came into her head.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If I eat one of these cakes,’ she thought, ‘it’s sure to make SOME change in my size; and as it can’t possibly make me larger, it must make me smaller, I suppose.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she swallowed one of the cakes, and was delighted to find that she began shrinking directly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As soon as she was small enough to get through the door, she ran out of the house, and found quite a crowd of little animals and birds waiting outside.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The poor little Lizard, Bill, was in the middle, being held up by two guinea-pigs, who were giving it something out of a bottle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They all made a rush at Alice the moment she appeared; but she ran off as hard as she could, and soon found herself safe in a thick wood.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The first thing I’ve got to do,’ said Alice to herself, as she wandered about in the wood, ‘is to grow to my right size again; and the second thing is to find my way into that lovely garden.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I think that will be the best plan.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It sounded an excellent plan, no doubt, and very neatly and simply arranged; the only difficulty was, that she had not the smallest idea how to set about it;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and while she was peering about anxiously among the trees, a little sharp bark just over her head made her look up in a great hurry.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: An enormous puppy was looking down at her with large round eyes, and feebly stretching out one paw, trying to touch her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Poor little thing!’ said Alice, in a coaxing tone, and she tried hard to whistle to it; but she was terribly frightened all the time at the thought that it might be hungry, in which case it would be very likely to eat her up in spite of all her coaxing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Hardly knowing what she did, she picked up a little bit of stick, and held it out to the puppy; whereupon the puppy jumped into the air off all its feet at once, with a yelp of delight, and rushed at the stick,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and made believe to worry it; then Alice dodged behind a great thistle, to keep herself from being run over; and the moment she appeared on the other side, the puppy made another rush at the stick, and tumbled head over heels in its hurry to get hold of it; then Alice,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: thinking it was very like having a game of play with a cart-horse, and expecting every moment to be trampled under its feet, ran round the thistle again; then the puppy began a series of short charges at the stick,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: running a very little way forwards each time and a long way back, and barking hoarsely all the while, till at last it sat down a good way off, panting, with its tongue hanging out of its mouth, and its great eyes half shut.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This seemed to Alice a good opportunity for making her escape; so she set off at once, and ran till she was quite tired and out of breath, and till the puppy’s bark sounded quite faint in the distance.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And yet what a dear little puppy it was!’ said Alice, as she leant against a buttercup to rest herself, and fanned herself with one of the leaves: ‘I should have liked teaching it tricks very much, if—if I’d only been the right size to do it!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Oh dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’d nearly forgotten that I’ve got to grow up again!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Let me see—how IS it to be managed?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I suppose I ought to eat or drink something or other; but the great question is, what?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The great question certainly was, what?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice looked all round her at the flowers and the blades of grass, but she did not see anything that looked like the right thing to eat or drink under the circumstances.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was a large mushroom growing near her, about the same height as herself; and when she had looked under it, and on both sides of it, and behind it, it occurred to her that she might as well look and see what was on the top of it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She stretched herself up on tiptoe, and peeped over the edge of the mushroom, and her eyes immediately met those of a large caterpillar, that was sitting on the top with its arms folded, quietly smoking a long hookah, and taking not the smallest notice of her or of anything else.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter V. Advice from a Caterpillar
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence: at last the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth, and addressed her in a languid, sleepy voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Who are YOU?’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This was not an encouraging opening for a conversation.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice replied, rather shyly, ‘I—I hardly know, sir, just at present—at least I know who I WAS when I got up this morning, but I think I must have been changed several times since then.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What do you mean by that?’ said the Caterpillar sternly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Explain yourself!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I can’t explain MYSELF, I’m afraid, sir’ said Alice, ‘because I’m not myself, you see.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t see,’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m afraid I can’t put it more clearly,’ Alice replied very politely, ‘for I can’t understand it myself to begin with; and being so many different sizes in a day is very confusing.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It isn’t,’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, perhaps you haven’t found it so yet,’ said Alice; ‘but when you have to turn into a chrysalis—you will some day, you know—and then after that into a butterfly, I should think you’ll feel it a little queer, won’t you?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not a bit,’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, perhaps your feelings may be different,’ said Alice; ‘all I know is, it would feel very queer to ME.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You!’ said the Caterpillar contemptuously.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Who are YOU?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Which brought them back again to the beginning of the conversation.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice felt a little irritated at the Caterpillar’s making such VERY short remarks, and she drew herself up and said, very gravely, ‘I think, you ought to tell me who YOU are, first.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why?’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Here was another puzzling question; and as Alice could not think of any good reason, and as the Caterpillar seemed to be in a VERY unpleasant state of mind, she turned away.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come back!’ the Caterpillar called after her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve something important to say!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This sounded promising, certainly: Alice turned and came back again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Keep your temper,’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Is that all?’ said Alice, swallowing down her anger as well as she could.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No,’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice thought she might as well wait, as she had nothing else to do, and perhaps after all it might tell her something worth hearing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: For some minutes it puffed away without speaking, but at last it unfolded its arms, took the hookah out of its mouth again, and said, ‘So you think you’re changed, do you?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m afraid I am, sir,’ said Alice; ‘I can’t remember things as I used—and I don’t keep the same size for ten minutes together!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Can’t remember WHAT things?’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, I’ve tried to say “HOW DOTH THE LITTLE BUSY BEE,” but it all came different!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice replied in a very melancholy voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Repeat, “YOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,”’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice folded her hands, and began:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘You are old, Father William,’ the young man said,
 ‘And your hair has become very white;
And yet you incessantly stand on your head—
 Do you think, at your age, it is right?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘In my youth,’ Father William replied to his son,
 ‘I feared it might injure the brain;
But, now that I’m perfectly sure I have none,
 Why, I do it again and again.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘You are old,’ said the youth, ‘as I mentioned before,
 And have grown most uncommonly fat;
Yet you turned a back-somersault in at the door—
 Pray, what is the reason of that?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘In my youth,’ said the sage, as he shook his grey locks,
 ‘I kept all my limbs very supple
By the use of this ointment—one shilling the box—
 Allow me to sell you a couple?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘You are old,’ said the youth, ‘and your jaws are too weak
 For anything tougher than suet;
Yet you finished the goose, with the bones and the beak—
 Pray how did you manage to do it?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘In my youth,’ said his father, ‘I took to the law,
 And argued each case with my wife;
And the muscular strength, which it gave to my jaw,
 Has lasted the rest of my life.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘You are old,’ said the youth, ‘one would hardly suppose
 That your eye was as steady as ever;
Yet you balanced an eel on the end of your nose—
 What made you so awfully clever?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘I have answered three questions, and that is enough,’
 Said his father; ‘don’t give yourself airs!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Do you think I can listen all day to such stuff?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Be off, or I’ll kick you down stairs!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That is not said right,’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not QUITE right, I’m afraid,’ said Alice, timidly; ‘some of the words have got altered.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It is wrong from beginning to end,’ said the Caterpillar decidedly, and there was silence for some minutes.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Caterpillar was the first to speak.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What size do you want to be?’ it asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, I’m not particular as to size,’ Alice hastily replied; ‘only one doesn’t like changing so often, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I DON’T know,’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice said nothing: she had never been so much contradicted in her life before, and she felt that she was losing her temper.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Are you content now?’ said the Caterpillar.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, I should like to be a LITTLE larger, sir, if you wouldn’t mind,’ said Alice: ‘three inches is such a wretched height to be.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It is a very good height indeed!’ said the Caterpillar angrily, rearing itself upright as it spoke (it was exactly three inches high).
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But I’m not used to it!’ pleaded poor Alice in a piteous tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she thought of herself, ‘I wish the creatures wouldn’t be so easily offended!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’ll get used to it in time,’ said the Caterpillar; and it put the hookah into its mouth and began smoking again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This time Alice waited patiently until it chose to speak again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: In a minute or two the Caterpillar took the hookah out of its mouth and yawned once or twice, and shook itself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then it got down off the mushroom, and crawled away in the grass, merely remarking as it went, ‘One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘One side of WHAT?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The other side of WHAT?’ thought Alice to herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of the mushroom,’ said the Caterpillar, just as if she had asked it aloud; and in another moment it was out of sight.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice remained looking thoughtfully at the mushroom for a minute, trying to make out which were the two sides of it; and as it was perfectly round, she found this a very difficult question.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, at last she stretched her arms round it as far as they would go, and broke off a bit of the edge with each hand.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And now which is which?’ she said to herself, and nibbled a little of the right-hand bit to try the effect: the next moment she felt a violent blow underneath her chin: it had struck her foot!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She was a good deal frightened by this very sudden change, but she felt that there was no time to be lost, as she was shrinking rapidly; so she set to work at once to eat some of the other bit.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Her chin was pressed so closely against her foot, that there was hardly room to open her mouth; but she did it at last, and managed to swallow a morsel of the lefthand bit.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What CAN all that green stuff be?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And where HAVE my shoulders got to?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And oh, my poor hands, how is it I can’t see you?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She was moving them about as she spoke, but no result seemed to follow, except a little shaking among the distant green leaves.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As there seemed to be no chance of getting her hands up to her head, she tried to get her head down to them, and was delighted to find that her neck would bend about easily in any direction, like a serpent.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She had just succeeded in curving it down into a graceful zigzag, and was going to dive in among the leaves, which she found to be nothing but the tops of the trees under which she had been wandering, when a sharp hiss made her draw back in a hurry:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: a large pigeon had flown into her face, and was beating her violently with its wings.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Serpent!’ screamed the Pigeon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m NOT a serpent!’ said Alice indignantly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Let me alone!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Serpent, I say again!’ repeated the Pigeon, but in a more subdued tone, and added with a kind of sob, ‘I’ve tried every way, and nothing seems to suit them!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I haven’t the least idea what you’re talking about,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve tried the roots of trees, and I’ve tried banks, and I’ve tried hedges,’ the Pigeon went on, without attending to her; ‘but those serpents!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There’s no pleasing them!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was more and more puzzled, but she thought there was no use in saying anything more till the Pigeon had finished.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘As if it wasn’t trouble enough hatching the eggs,’ said the Pigeon; ‘but I must be on the look-out for serpents night and day!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Why, I haven’t had a wink of sleep these three weeks!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m very sorry you’ve been annoyed,’ said Alice, who was beginning to see its meaning.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And just as I’d taken the highest tree in the wood,’ continued the Pigeon, raising its voice to a shriek, ‘and just as I was thinking I should be free of them at last, they must needs come wriggling down from the sky!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Ugh, Serpent!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But I’m NOT a serpent, I tell you!’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m a—I’m a—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: WHAT are you?’ said the Pigeon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I can see you’re trying to invent something!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I—I’m a little girl,’ said Alice, rather doubtfully, as she remembered the number of changes she had gone through that day.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘A likely story indeed!’ said the Pigeon in a tone of the deepest contempt.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve seen a good many little girls in my time, but never ONE with such a neck as that!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: No, no!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: You’re a serpent; and there’s no use denying it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I suppose you’ll be telling me next that you never tasted an egg!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I HAVE tasted eggs, certainly,’ said Alice, who was a very truthful child; ‘but little girls eat eggs quite as much as serpents do, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t believe it,’ said the Pigeon; ‘but if they do, why then they’re a kind of serpent, that’s all I can say.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This was such a new idea to Alice, that she was quite silent for a minute or two, which gave the Pigeon the opportunity of adding, ‘You’re looking for eggs, I know THAT well enough; and what does it matter to me whether you’re a little girl or a serpent?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It matters a good deal to ME,’ said Alice hastily; ‘but I’m not looking for eggs, as it happens; and if I was, I shouldn’t want YOURS: I don’t like them raw.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, be off, then!’ said the Pigeon in a sulky tone, as it settled down again into its nest.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice crouched down among the trees as well as she could, for her neck kept getting entangled among the branches, and every now and then she had to stop and untwist it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: After a while she remembered that she still held the pieces of mushroom in her hands, and she set to work very carefully, nibbling first at one and then at the other, and growing sometimes taller and sometimes shorter,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: until she had succeeded in bringing herself down to her usual height.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was so long since she had been anything near the right size, that it felt quite strange at first; but she got used to it in a few minutes, and began talking to herself, as usual.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come, there’s half my plan done now!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: How puzzling all these changes are!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’m never sure what I’m going to be, from one minute to another!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, I’ve got back to my right size: the next thing is, to get into that beautiful garden—how IS that to be done, I wonder?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As she said this, she came suddenly upon an open place, with a little house in it about four feet high.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Whoever lives there,’ thought Alice, ‘it’ll never do to come upon them THIS size: why, I should frighten them out of their wits!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she began nibbling at the righthand bit again, and did not venture to go near the house till she had brought herself down to nine inches high.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter VI. Pig and Pepper
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what to do next, when suddenly a footman in livery came running out of the wood—( she considered him to be a footman because he was in livery:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: otherwise, judging by his face only, she would have called him a fish)—and rapped loudly at the door with his knuckles.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was opened by another footman in livery, with a round face, and large eyes like a frog; and both footmen, Alice noticed, had powdered hair that curled all over their heads.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She felt very curious to know what it was all about, and crept a little way out of the wood to listen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Fish-Footman began by producing from under his arm a great letter, nearly as large as himself, and this he handed over to the other, saying, in a solemn tone, ‘For the Duchess.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: An invitation from the Queen to play croquet.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Frog-Footman repeated, in the same solemn tone, only changing the order of the words a little, ‘From the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: An invitation for the Duchess to play croquet.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then they both bowed low, and their curls got entangled together.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice laughed so much at this, that she had to run back into the wood for fear of their hearing her; and when she next peeped out the Fish-Footman was gone, and the other was sitting on the ground near the door, staring stupidly up into the sky.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice went timidly up to the door, and knocked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There’s no sort of use in knocking,’ said the Footman, ‘and that for two reasons.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: First, because I’m on the same side of the door as you are; secondly, because they’re making such a noise inside, no one could possibly hear you.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And certainly there was a most extraordinary noise going on within—a constant howling and sneezing, and every now and then a great crash, as if a dish or kettle had been broken to pieces.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Please, then,’ said Alice, ‘how am I to get in?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There might be some sense in your knocking,’ the Footman went on without attending to her, ‘if we had the door between us.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: For instance, if you were INSIDE, you might knock, and I could let you out, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He was looking up into the sky all the time he was speaking, and this Alice thought decidedly uncivil.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But perhaps he can’t help it,’ she said to herself; ‘his eyes are so VERY nearly at the top of his head.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But at any rate he might answer questions.—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: How am I to get in?’ she repeated, aloud.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I shall sit here,’ the Footman remarked, ‘till tomorrow—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: At this moment the door of the house opened, and a large plate came skimming out, straight at the Footman’s head: it just grazed his nose, and broke to pieces against one of the trees behind him.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—or next day, maybe,’ the Footman continued in the same tone, exactly as if nothing had happened.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How am I to get in?’ asked Alice again, in a louder tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘ARE you to get in at all?’ said the Footman.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s the first question, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was, no doubt: only Alice did not like to be told so.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s really dreadful,’ she muttered to herself, ‘the way all the creatures argue.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It’s enough to drive one crazy!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Footman seemed to think this a good opportunity for repeating his remark, with variations.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I shall sit here,’ he said, ‘on and off, for days and days.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But what am I to do?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Anything you like,’ said the Footman, and began whistling.
