tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, there’s no use in talking to him,’ said Alice desperately: ‘he’s perfectly idiotic!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she opened the door and went in.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There’s certainly too much pepper in that soup!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice said to herself, as well as she could for sneezing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was certainly too much of it in the air.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Even the Duchess sneezed occasionally; and as for the baby, it was sneezing and howling alternately without a moment’s pause.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The only things in the kitchen that did not sneeze, were the cook, and a large cat which was sitting on the hearth and grinning from ear to ear.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Please would you tell me,’ said Alice, a little timidly, for she was not quite sure whether it was good manners for her to speak first, ‘why your cat grins like that?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s a Cheshire cat,’ said the Duchess, ‘and that’s why.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Pig!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She said the last word with such sudden violence that Alice quite jumped; but she saw in another moment that it was addressed to the baby, and not to her, so she took courage, and went on again:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I didn’t know that Cheshire cats always grinned; in fact, I didn’t know that cats COULD grin.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They all can,’ said the Duchess; ‘and most of ‘em do.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t know of any that do,’ Alice said very politely, feeling quite pleased to have got into a conversation.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You don’t know much,’ said the Duchess; ‘and that’s a fact.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice did not at all like the tone of this remark, and thought it would be as well to introduce some other subject of conversation.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: While she was trying to fix on one, the cook took the cauldron of soup off the fire, and at once set to work throwing everything within her reach at the Duchess and the baby—the fire-irons came first; then followed a shower of saucepans, plates, and dishes.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Duchess took no notice of them even when they hit her; and the baby was howling so much already, that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, PLEASE mind what you’re doing!’ cried Alice, jumping up and down in an agony of terror.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, there goes his PRECIOUS nose’; as an unusually large saucepan flew close by it, and very nearly carried it off.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If everybody minded their own business,’ the Duchess said in a hoarse growl, ‘the world would go round a deal faster than it does.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Which would NOT be an advantage,’ said Alice, who felt very glad to get an opportunity of showing off a little of her knowledge.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Just think of what work it would make with the day and night!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: You see the earth takes twenty-four hours to turn round on its axis—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Talking of axes,’ said the Duchess, ‘chop off her head!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice glanced rather anxiously at the cook, to see if she meant to take the hint; but the cook was busily stirring the soup, and seemed not to be listening, so she went on again: ‘Twenty-four hours, I THINK; or is it twelve?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, don’t bother ME,’ said the Duchess; ‘I never could abide figures!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And with that she began nursing her child again, singing a sort of lullaby to it as she did so, and giving it a violent shake at the end of every line:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘Speak roughly to your little boy,
 And beat him when he sneezes:
He only does it to annoy,
 Because he knows it teases.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (In which the cook and the baby joined):—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Wow! wow! wow!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: While the Duchess sang the second verse of the song, she kept tossing the baby violently up and down, and the poor little thing howled so, that Alice could hardly hear the words:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘I speak severely to my boy,
 I beat him when he sneezes;
For he can thoroughly enjoy
 The pepper when he pleases!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Wow! wow! wow!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Here! you may nurse it a bit, if you like!’ the Duchess said to Alice, flinging the baby at her as she spoke.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I must go and get ready to play croquet with the Queen,’ and she hurried out of the room.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The cook threw a frying-pan after her as she went out, but it just missed her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice caught the baby with some difficulty, as it was a queer-shaped little creature, and held out its arms and legs in all directions, ‘just like a star-fish,’ thought Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The poor little thing was snorting like a steam-engine when she caught it, and kept doubling itself up and straightening itself out again, so that altogether, for the first minute or two, it was as much as she could do to hold it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As soon as she had made out the proper way of nursing it, (which was to twist it up into a sort of knot, and then keep tight hold of its right ear and left foot, so as to prevent its undoing itself,) she carried it out into the open air.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘IF I don’t take this child away with me,’ thought Alice, ‘they’re sure to kill it in a day or two: wouldn’t it be murder to leave it behind?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She said the last words out loud, and the little thing grunted in reply (it had left off sneezing by this time).
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Don’t grunt,’ said Alice; ‘that’s not at all a proper way of expressing yourself.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The baby grunted again, and Alice looked very anxiously into its face to see what was the matter with it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There could be no doubt that it had a VERY turn-up nose, much more like a snout than a real nose; also its eyes were getting extremely small for a baby: altogether Alice did not like the look of the thing at all.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But perhaps it was only sobbing,’ she thought, and looked into its eyes again, to see if there were any tears.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: No, there were no tears.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If you’re going to turn into a pig, my dear,’ said Alice, seriously, ‘I’ll have nothing more to do with you.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Mind now!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The poor little thing sobbed again (or grunted, it was impossible to say which), and they went on for some while in silence.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was just beginning to think to herself, ‘Now, what am I to do with this creature when I get it home?’ when it grunted again, so violently, that she looked down into its face in some alarm.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This time there could be NO mistake about it: it was neither more nor less than a pig, and she felt that it would be quite absurd for her to carry it further.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she set the little creature down, and felt quite relieved to see it trot away quietly into the wood.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If it had grown up,’ she said to herself, ‘it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes rather a handsome pig, I think.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she began thinking over other children she knew, who might do very well as pigs, and was just saying to herself, ‘if one only knew the right way to change them—’ when she was a little startled by seeing the Cheshire Cat sitting on a bough of a tree a few yards off.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Cat only grinned when it saw Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It looked good-natured, she thought: still it had VERY long claws and a great many teeth, so she felt that it ought to be treated with respect.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Cheshire Puss,’ she began, rather timidly, as she did not at all know whether it would like the name: however, it only grinned a little wider.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come, it’s pleased so far,’ thought Alice, and she went on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Would you tell me, please, which way I ought to go from here?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That depends a good deal on where you want to get to,’ said the Cat.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t much care where—’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then it doesn’t matter which way you go,’ said the Cat.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—so long as I get SOMEWHERE,’ Alice added as an explanation.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, you’re sure to do that,’ said the Cat, ‘if you only walk long enough.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice felt that this could not be denied, so she tried another question.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What sort of people live about here?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘In THAT direction,’ the Cat said, waving its right paw round, ‘lives a Hatter: and in THAT direction,’ waving the other paw, ‘lives a March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Visit either you like: they’re both mad.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But I don’t want to go among mad people,’ Alice remarked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, you can’t help that,’ said the Cat: ‘we’re all mad here.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’m mad.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: You’re mad.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How do you know I’m mad?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You must be,’ said the Cat, ‘or you wouldn’t have come here.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice didn’t think that proved it at all; however, she went on ‘And how do you know that you’re mad?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘To begin with,’ said the Cat, ‘a dog’s not mad.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: You grant that?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I suppose so,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, then,’ the Cat went on, ‘you see, a dog growls when it’s angry, and wags its tail when it’s pleased.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Now I growl when I’m pleased, and wag my tail when I’m angry.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Therefore I’m mad.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I call it purring, not growling,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Call it what you like,’ said the Cat.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Do you play croquet with the Queen to-day?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I should like it very much,’ said Alice, ‘but I haven’t been invited yet.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’ll see me there,’ said the Cat, and vanished.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was not much surprised at this, she was getting so used to queer things happening.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: While she was looking at the place where it had been, it suddenly appeared again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘By-the-bye, what became of the baby?’ said the Cat.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’d nearly forgotten to ask.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It turned into a pig,’ Alice quietly said, just as if it had come back in a natural way.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I thought it would,’ said the Cat, and vanished again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice waited a little, half expecting to see it again, but it did not appear, and after a minute or two she walked on in the direction in which the March Hare was said to live.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve seen hatters before,’ she said to herself; ‘the March Hare will be much the most interesting, and perhaps as this is May it won’t be raving mad—at least not so mad as it was in March.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As she said this, she looked up, and there was the Cat again, sitting on a branch of a tree.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Did you say pig, or fig?’ said the Cat.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I said pig,’ replied Alice; ‘and I wish you wouldn’t keep appearing and vanishing so suddenly: you make one quite giddy.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘All right,’ said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly, beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which remained some time after the rest of it had gone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’ve often seen a cat without a grin,’ thought Alice; ‘but a grin without a cat!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It’s the most curious thing I ever saw in my life!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She had not gone much farther before she came in sight of the house of the March Hare: she thought it must be the right house, because the chimneys were shaped like ears and the roof was thatched with fur.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It was so large a house, that she did not like to go nearer till she had nibbled some more of the lefthand bit of mushroom, and raised herself to about two feet high: even then she walked up towards it rather timidly, saying to herself ‘Suppose it should be raving mad after all!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I almost wish I’d gone to see the Hatter instead!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter VII. A Mad Tea-Party
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it: a Dormouse was sitting between them, fast asleep, and the other two were using it as a cushion, resting their elbows on it, and talking over its head.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Very uncomfortable for the Dormouse,’ thought Alice; ‘only, as it’s asleep, I suppose it doesn’t mind.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The table was a large one, but the three were all crowded together at one corner of it: ‘No room!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: No room!’ they cried out when they saw Alice coming.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There’s PLENTY of room!’ said Alice indignantly, and she sat down in a large arm-chair at one end of the table.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Have some wine,’ the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice looked all round the table, but there was nothing on it but tea.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t see any wine,’ she remarked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There isn’t any,’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then it wasn’t very civil of you to offer it,’ said Alice angrily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It wasn’t very civil of you to sit down without being invited,’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I didn’t know it was YOUR table,’ said Alice; ‘it’s laid for a great many more than three.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Your hair wants cutting,’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He had been looking at Alice for some time with great curiosity, and this was his first speech.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You should learn not to make personal remarks,’ Alice said with some severity; ‘it’s very rude.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Hatter opened his eyes very wide on hearing this; but all he SAID was, ‘Why is a raven like a writing-desk?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come, we shall have some fun now!’ thought Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m glad they’ve begun asking riddles.—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I believe I can guess that,’ she added aloud.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Do you mean that you think you can find out the answer to it?’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Exactly so,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then you should say what you mean,’ the March Hare went on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I do,’ Alice hastily replied; ‘at least—at least I mean what I say—that’s the same thing, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not the same thing a bit!’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You might just as well say that “I see what I eat” is the same thing as “I eat what I see”!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You might just as well say,’ added the March Hare, ‘that “I like what I get” is the same thing as “I get what I like”!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You might just as well say,’ added the Dormouse, who seemed to be talking in his sleep, ‘that “I breathe when I sleep” is the same thing as “I sleep when I breathe”!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It IS the same thing with you,’ said the Hatter, and here the conversation dropped, and the party sat silent for a minute, while Alice thought over all she could remember about ravens and writing-desks, which wasn’t much.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Hatter was the first to break the silence.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What day of the month is it?’ he said, turning to Alice: he had taken his watch out of his pocket, and was looking at it uneasily, shaking it every now and then, and holding it to his ear.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice considered a little, and then said ‘The fourth.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Two days wrong!’ sighed the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I told you butter wouldn’t suit the works!’ he added looking angrily at the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It was the BEST butter,’ the March Hare meekly replied.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes, but some crumbs must have got in as well,’ the Hatter grumbled: ‘you shouldn’t have put it in with the bread-knife.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The March Hare took the watch and looked at it gloomily: then he dipped it into his cup of tea, and looked at it again: but he could think of nothing better to say than his first remark, ‘It was the BEST butter, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice had been looking over his shoulder with some curiosity.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What a funny watch!’ she remarked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It tells the day of the month, and doesn’t tell what o’clock it is!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why should it?’ muttered the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Does YOUR watch tell you what year it is?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course not,’ Alice replied very readily: ‘but that’s because it stays the same year for such a long time together.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Which is just the case with MINE,’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice felt dreadfully puzzled.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Hatter’s remark seemed to have no sort of meaning in it, and yet it was certainly English.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t quite understand you,’ she said, as politely as she could.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The Dormouse is asleep again,’ said the Hatter, and he poured a little hot tea upon its nose.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Dormouse shook its head impatiently, and said, without opening its eyes, ‘Of course, of course; just what I was going to remark myself.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Have you guessed the riddle yet?’ the Hatter said, turning to Alice again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, I give it up,’ Alice replied: ‘what’s the answer?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I haven’t the slightest idea,’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nor I,’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice sighed wearily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I think you might do something better with the time,’ she said, ‘than waste it in asking riddles that have no answers.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If you knew Time as well as I do,’ said the Hatter, ‘you wouldn’t talk about wasting IT.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It’s HIM.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t know what you mean,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course you don’t!’ the Hatter said, tossing his head contemptuously.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I dare say you never even spoke to Time!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Perhaps not,’ Alice cautiously replied: ‘but I know I have to beat time when I learn music.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Ah! that accounts for it,’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘He won’t stand beating.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Now, if you only kept on good terms with him, he’d do almost anything you liked with the clock.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: For instance, suppose it were nine o’clock in the morning, just time to begin lessons: you’d only have to whisper a hint to Time, and round goes the clock in a twinkling!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Half-past one, time for dinner!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: [‘I only wish it was,’ the March Hare said to itself in a whisper.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That would be grand, certainly,’ said Alice thoughtfully: ‘but then—I shouldn’t be hungry for it, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not at first, perhaps,’ said the Hatter: ‘but you could keep it to half-past one as long as you liked.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Is that the way YOU manage?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Hatter shook his head mournfully.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not I!’ he replied.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘We quarrelled last March—just before HE went mad, you know—’ (pointing with his tea spoon at the March Hare,) ‘—it was at the great concert given by the Queen of Hearts, and I had to sing
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “Twinkle, twinkle, little bat!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: How I wonder what you’re at!”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: You know the song, perhaps?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve heard something like it,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It goes on, you know,’ the Hatter continued, ‘in this way:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
“Up above the world you fly,
Like a tea-tray in the sky.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Twinkle, twinkle—“’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Here the Dormouse shook itself, and began singing in its sleep ‘Twinkle, twinkle, twinkle, twinkle—’ and went on so long that they had to pinch it to make it stop.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, I’d hardly finished the first verse,’ said the Hatter, ‘when the Queen jumped up and bawled out, “He’s murdering the time!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Off with his head!”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How dreadfully savage!’ exclaimed Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And ever since that,’ the Hatter went on in a mournful tone, ‘he won’t do a thing I ask!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It’s always six o’clock now.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: A bright idea came into Alice’s head.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Is that the reason so many tea-things are put out here?’ she asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes, that’s it,’ said the Hatter with a sigh: ‘it’s always tea-time, and we’ve no time to wash the things between whiles.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then you keep moving round, I suppose?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Exactly so,’ said the Hatter: ‘as the things get used up.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But what happens when you come to the beginning again?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice ventured to ask.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Suppose we change the subject,’ the March Hare interrupted, yawning.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m getting tired of this.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I vote the young lady tells us a story.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m afraid I don’t know one,’ said Alice, rather alarmed at the proposal.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then the Dormouse shall!’ they both cried.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Wake up, Dormouse!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And they pinched it on both sides at once.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Dormouse slowly opened his eyes.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wasn’t asleep,’ he said in a hoarse, feeble voice: ‘I heard every word you fellows were saying.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Tell us a story!’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes, please do!’ pleaded Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And be quick about it,’ added the Hatter, ‘or you’ll be asleep again before it’s done.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Once upon a time there were three little sisters,’ the Dormouse began in a great hurry; ‘and their names were Elsie, Lacie, and Tillie; and they lived at the bottom of a well—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What did they live on?’ said Alice, who always took a great interest in questions of eating and drinking.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They lived on treacle,’ said the Dormouse, after thinking a minute or two.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They couldn’t have done that, you know,’ Alice gently remarked; ‘they’d have been ill.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘So they were,’ said the Dormouse; ‘VERY ill.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice tried to fancy to herself what such an extraordinary ways of living would be like, but it puzzled her too much, so she went on: ‘But why did they live at the bottom of a well?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Take some more tea,’ the March Hare said to Alice, very earnestly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve had nothing yet,’ Alice replied in an offended tone, ‘so I can’t take more.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You mean you can’t take LESS,’ said the Hatter: ‘it’s very easy to take MORE than nothing.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nobody asked YOUR opinion,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Who’s making personal remarks now?’ the Hatter asked triumphantly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice did not quite know what to say to this: so she helped herself to some tea and bread-and-butter, and then turned to the Dormouse, and repeated her question.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why did they live at the bottom of a well?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Dormouse again took a minute or two to think about it, and then said, ‘It was a treacle-well.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There’s no such thing!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was beginning very angrily, but the Hatter and the March Hare went ‘Sh! sh!’ and the Dormouse sulkily remarked, ‘If you can’t be civil, you’d better finish the story for yourself.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, please go on!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice said very humbly; ‘I won’t interrupt again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I dare say there may be ONE.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘One, indeed!’ said the Dormouse indignantly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, he consented to go on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And so these three little sisters—they were learning to draw, you know—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What did they draw?’ said Alice, quite forgetting her promise.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Treacle,’ said the Dormouse, without considering at all this time.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I want a clean cup,’ interrupted the Hatter: ‘let’s all move one place on.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He moved on as he spoke, and the Dormouse followed him: the March Hare moved into the Dormouse’s place, and Alice rather unwillingly took the place of the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Hatter was the only one who got any advantage from the change: and Alice was a good deal worse off than before, as the March Hare had just upset the milk-jug into his plate.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice did not wish to offend the Dormouse again, so she began very cautiously: ‘But I don’t understand.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Where did they draw the treacle from?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You can draw water out of a water-well,’ said the Hatter; ‘so I should think you could draw treacle out of a treacle-well—eh, stupid?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But they were IN the well,’ Alice said to the Dormouse, not choosing to notice this last remark.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course they were’, said the Dormouse; ‘—well in.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This answer so confused poor Alice, that she let the Dormouse go on for some time without interrupting it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They were learning to draw,’ the Dormouse went on, yawning and rubbing its eyes, for it was getting very sleepy; ‘and they drew all manner of things—everything that begins with an M—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why with an M?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why not?’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was silent.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Dormouse had closed its eyes by this time, and was going off into a doze; but, on being pinched by the Hatter, it woke up again with a little shriek, and went on:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—that begins with an M, such as mouse-traps, and the moon, and memory, and muchness—you know you say things are “much of a muchness”—did you ever see such a thing as a drawing of a muchness?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Really, now you ask me,’ said Alice, very much confused, ‘I don’t think—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then you shouldn’t talk,’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This piece of rudeness was more than Alice could bear: she got up in great disgust, and walked off;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: the Dormouse fell asleep instantly, and neither of the others took the least notice of her going, though she looked back once or twice, half hoping that they would call after her: the last time she saw them, they were trying to put the Dormouse into the teapot.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘At any rate I’ll never go THERE again!’ said Alice as she picked her way through the wood.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s the stupidest tea-party I ever was at in all my life!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Just as she said this, she noticed that one of the trees had a door leading right into it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s very curious!’ she thought.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But everything’s curious today.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I think I may as well go in at once.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And in she went.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Once more she found herself in the long hall, and close to the little glass table.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Now, I’ll manage better this time,’ she said to herself, and began by taking the little golden key, and unlocking the door that led into the garden.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then she went to work nibbling at the mushroom (she had kept a piece of it in her pocket) till she was about a foot high: then she walked down the little passage: and THEN—she found herself at last in the beautiful garden, among the bright flower-beds and the cool fountains.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter VIII. The Queen’s Croquet-Ground
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: A large rose-tree stood near the entrance of the garden: the roses growing on it were white, but there were three gardeners at it, busily painting them red.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice thought this a very curious thing, and she went nearer to watch them, and just as she came up to them she heard one of them say, ‘Look out now, Five!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Don’t go splashing paint over me like that!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I couldn’t help it,’ said Five, in a sulky tone; ‘Seven jogged my elbow.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: On which Seven looked up and said, ‘That’s right, Five!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Always lay the blame on others!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘YOU’D better not talk!’ said Five.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I heard the Queen say only yesterday you deserved to be beheaded!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What for?’ said the one who had spoken first.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s none of YOUR business, Two!’ said Seven.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes, it IS his business!’ said Five, ‘and I’ll tell him—it was for bringing the cook tulip-roots instead of onions.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Seven flung down his brush, and had just begun ‘Well, of all the unjust things—’ when his eye chanced to fall upon Alice, as she stood watching them, and he checked himself suddenly: the others looked round also, and all of them bowed low.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Would you tell me,’ said Alice, a little timidly, ‘why you are painting those roses?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Five and Seven said nothing, but looked at Two.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Two began in a low voice, ‘Why the fact is, you see, Miss, this here ought to have been a RED rose-tree, and we put a white one in by mistake; and if the Queen was to find it out, we should all have our heads cut off, you know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So you see, Miss, we’re doing our best, afore she comes, to—’ At this moment Five, who had been anxiously looking across the garden, called out ‘The Queen!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Queen!’ and the three gardeners instantly threw themselves flat upon their faces.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was a sound of many footsteps, and Alice looked round, eager to see the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: First came ten soldiers carrying clubs; these were all shaped like the three gardeners, oblong and flat, with their hands and feet at the corners: next the ten courtiers; these were ornamented all over with diamonds, and walked two and two, as the soldiers did.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: After these came the royal children; there were ten of them, and the little dears came jumping merrily along hand in hand, in couples: they were all ornamented with hearts.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Next came the guests, mostly Kings and Queens, and among them Alice recognised the White Rabbit: it was talking in a hurried nervous manner, smiling at everything that was said, and went by without noticing her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then followed the Knave of Hearts, carrying the King’s crown on a crimson velvet cushion; and, last of all this grand procession, came THE KING AND QUEEN OF HEARTS.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was rather doubtful whether she ought not to lie down on her face like the three gardeners, but she could not remember ever having heard of such a rule at processions;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘and besides, what would be the use of a procession,’ thought she, ‘if people had all to lie down upon their faces, so that they couldn’t see it?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she stood still where she was, and waited.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: When the procession came opposite to Alice, they all stopped and looked at her, and the Queen said severely ‘Who is this?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She said it to the Knave of Hearts, who only bowed and smiled in reply.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Idiot!’ said the Queen, tossing her head impatiently; and, turning to Alice, she went on, ‘What’s your name, child?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘My name is Alice, so please your Majesty,’ said Alice very politely; but she added, to herself, ‘Why, they’re only a pack of cards, after all.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I needn’t be afraid of them!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And who are THESE?’ said the Queen, pointing to the three gardeners who were lying round the rosetree;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: for, you see, as they were lying on their faces, and the pattern on their backs was the same as the rest of the pack, she could not tell whether they were gardeners, or soldiers, or courtiers, or three of her own children.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How should I know?’ said Alice, surprised at her own courage.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s no business of MINE.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Queen turned crimson with fury, and, after glaring at her for a moment like a wild beast, screamed ‘Off with her head!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Off—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nonsense!’ said Alice, very loudly and decidedly, and the Queen was silent.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The King laid his hand upon her arm, and timidly said ‘Consider, my dear: she is only a child!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Queen turned angrily away from him, and said to the Knave ‘Turn them over!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Knave did so, very carefully, with one foot.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Get up!’ said the Queen, in a shrill, loud voice, and the three gardeners instantly jumped up, and began bowing to the King, the Queen, the royal children, and everybody else.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Leave off that!’ screamed the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You make me giddy.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And then, turning to the rose-tree, she went on, ‘What HAVE you been doing here?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘May it please your Majesty,’ said Two, in a very humble tone, going down on one knee as he spoke, ‘we were trying—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I see!’ said the Queen, who had meanwhile been examining the roses.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Off with their heads!’ and the procession moved on, three of the soldiers remaining behind to execute the unfortunate gardeners, who ran to Alice for protection.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You shan’t be beheaded!’ said Alice, and she put them into a large flower-pot that stood near.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The three soldiers wandered about for a minute or two, looking for them, and then quietly marched off after the others.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Are their heads off?’ shouted the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Their heads are gone, if it please your Majesty!’ the soldiers shouted in reply.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s right!’ shouted the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Can you play croquet?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The soldiers were silent, and looked at Alice, as the question was evidently meant for her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes!’ shouted Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come on, then!’ roared the Queen, and Alice joined the procession, wondering very much what would happen next.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s—it’s a very fine day!’ said a timid voice at her side.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She was walking by the White Rabbit, who was peeping anxiously into her face.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Very,’ said Alice: ‘—where’s the Duchess?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Hush!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Hush!’ said the Rabbit in a low, hurried tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He looked anxiously over his shoulder as he spoke, and then raised himself upon tiptoe, put his mouth close to her ear, and whispered ‘She’s under sentence of execution.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What for?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Did you say “What a pity!”?’ the Rabbit asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, I didn’t,’ said Alice: ‘I don’t think it’s at all a pity.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I said “What for?”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘She boxed the Queen’s ears—’ the Rabbit began.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice gave a little scream of laughter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, hush!’ the Rabbit whispered in a frightened tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The Queen will hear you!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: You see, she came rather late, and the Queen said—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Get to your places!’ shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo: she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head, it WOULD twist itself round and look up in her face, with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin again,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to, and,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting ‘Off with his head!’ or ‘Off with her head!’ about once in a minute.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, ‘and then,’ thought she, ‘what would become of me?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They’re dreadfully fond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there’s any one left alive!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself ‘It’s the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk to.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How are you getting on?’ said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s no use speaking to it,’ she thought, ‘till its ears have come, or at least one of them.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t think they play at all fairly,’ Alice began, in rather a complaining tone, ‘and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can’t hear oneself speak—and they don’t seem to have any rules in particular;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: at least, if there are, nobody attends to them—and you’ve no idea how confusing it is all the things being alive;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: for instance, there’s the arch I’ve got to go through next walking about at the other end of the ground—and I should have croqueted the Queen’s hedgehog just now, only it ran away when it saw mine coming!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How do you like the Queen?’ said the Cat in a low voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not at all,’ said Alice: ‘she’s so extremely—’ Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, ‘—likely to win, that it’s hardly worth while finishing the game.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Queen smiled and passed on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Who ARE you talking to?’ said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat’s head with great curiosity.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s a friend of mine—a Cheshire Cat,’ said Alice: ‘allow me to introduce it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t like the look of it at all,’ said the King: ‘however, it may kiss my hand if it likes.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’d rather not,’ the Cat remarked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Don’t be impertinent,’ said the King, ‘and don’t look at me like that!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He got behind Alice as he spoke.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘A cat may look at a king,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve read that in some book, but I don’t remember where.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, it must be removed,’ said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment, ‘My dear!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I wish you would have this cat removed!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Off with his head!’ she said, without even looking round.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ll fetch the executioner myself,’ said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen’s voice in the distance, screaming with passion.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she went in search of her hedgehog.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight: ‘but it doesn’t matter much,’ thought Alice, ‘as all the arches are gone from this side of the ground.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The executioner’s argument was, that you couldn’t cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn’t going to begin at HIS time of life.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The King’s argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren’t to talk nonsense.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Queen’s argument was, that if something wasn’t done about it in less than no time she’d have everybody executed, all round.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice could think of nothing else to say but ‘It belongs to the Duchess: you’d better ask HER about it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘She’s in prison,’ the Queen said to the executioner: ‘fetch her here.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And the executioner went off like an arrow.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Cat’s head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter IX. The Mock Turtle’s Story
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You can’t think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!’ said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice’s, and they walked off together.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘When I’M a Duchess,’ she said to herself, (not in a very hopeful tone though), ‘I won’t have any pepper in my kitchen AT ALL.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Soup does very well without—Maybe it’s always pepper that makes people hot-tempered,’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she went on, very much pleased at having found out a new kind of rule, ‘and vinegar that makes them sour—and camomile that makes them bitter—and—and barley-sugar and such things that make children sweet-tempered.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn’t be so stingy about it, you know—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’re thinking about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I can’t tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in a bit.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Perhaps it hasn’t one,’ Alice ventured to remark.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Tut, tut, child!’ said the Duchess.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Everything’s got a moral, if only you can find it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice’s side as she spoke.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was VERY ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice’s shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The game’s going on rather better now,’ she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘’Tis so,’ said the Duchess: ‘and the moral of that is—“ Oh, ‘tis love, ‘tis love, that makes the world go round!”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Somebody said,’ Alice whispered, ‘that it’s done by everybody minding their own business!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Ah, well!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It means much the same thing,’ said the Duchess, digging her sharp little chin into Alice’s shoulder as she added, ‘and the moral of THAT is—“ Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of themselves.”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How fond she is of finding morals in things!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice thought to herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I dare say you’re wondering why I don’t put my arm round your waist,’ the Duchess said after a pause: ‘the reason is, that I’m doubtful about the temper of your flamingo.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Shall I try the experiment?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘HE might bite,’ Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Very true,’ said the Duchess: ‘flamingoes and mustard both bite.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And the moral of that is—“ Birds of a feather flock together.”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Only mustard isn’t a bird,’ Alice remarked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Right, as usual,’ said the Duchess: ‘what a clear way you have of putting things!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s a mineral, I THINK,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course it is,’ said the Duchess, who seemed ready to agree to everything that Alice said; ‘there’s a large mustard-mine near here.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And the moral of that is—“ The more there is of mine, the less there is of yours.”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, I know!’ exclaimed Alice, who had not attended to this last remark, ‘it’s a vegetable.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It doesn’t look like one, but it is.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I quite agree with you,’ said the Duchess; ‘and the moral of that is—“ Be what you would seem to be”—or if you’d like it put more simply—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “ Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might appear to others that what you were or might have been was not otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be otherwise.”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I think I should understand that better,’ Alice said very politely, ‘if I had it written down: but I can’t quite follow it as you say it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s nothing to what I could say if I chose,’ the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Pray don’t trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, don’t talk about trouble!’ said the Duchess.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I make you a present of everything I’ve said as yet.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘A cheap sort of present!’ thought Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m glad they don’t give birthday presents like that!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But she did not venture to say it out loud.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Thinking again?’ the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve a right to think,’ said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Just about as much right,’ said the Duchess, ‘as pigs have to fly; and the m—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But here, to Alice’s great surprise, the Duchess’s voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word ‘moral,’ and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘A fine day, your Majesty!’ the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Now, I give you fair warning,’ shouted the Queen, stamping on the ground as she spoke; ‘either you or your head must be off, and that in about half no time!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Take your choice!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Let’s go on with the game,’ the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen’s absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment’s delay would cost them their lives.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting ‘Off with his head!’ or ‘Off with her head!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: were in custody and under sentence of execution.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice, ‘Have you seen the Mock Turtle yet?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t even know what a Mock Turtle is.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,’ said the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I never saw one, or heard of one,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come on, then,’ said the Queen, ‘and he shall tell you his history,’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally, ‘You are all pardoned.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come, THAT’S a good thing!’ she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (IF you don’t know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Up, lazy thing!’ said the Queen, ‘and take this young lady to see the Mock Turtle, and to hear his history.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I must go back and see after some executions I have ordered’; and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What fun!’ said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What IS the fun?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why, SHE,’ said the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s all her fancy, that: they never executes nobody, you know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Come on!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Everybody says “come on!” here,’ thought Alice, as she went slowly after it: ‘I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She pitied him deeply.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What is his sorrow?’ she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before, ‘It’s all his fancy, that: he hasn’t got no sorrow, you know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Come on!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘This here young lady,’ said the Gryphon, ‘she wants for to know your history, she do.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ll tell it her,’ said the Mock Turtle in a deep, hollow tone: ‘sit down, both of you, and don’t speak a word till I’ve finished.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice thought to herself, ‘I don’t see how he can EVEN finish, if he doesn’t begin.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But she waited patiently.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Once,’ said the Mock Turtle at last, with a deep sigh, ‘I was a real Turtle.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of ‘Hjckrrh!’ from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, ‘Thank you, sir, for your interesting story,’ but she could not help thinking there MUST be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘When we were little,’ the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, ‘we went to school in the sea.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The master was an old Turtle—we used to call him Tortoise—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn’t one?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘We called him Tortoise because he taught us,’ said the Mock Turtle angrily: ‘really you are very dull!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple question,’ added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle, ‘Drive on, old fellow!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Don’t be all day about it!’ and he went on in these words:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn’t believe it—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I never said I didn’t!’ interrupted Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You did,’ said the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Hold your tongue!’ added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mock Turtle went on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘We had the best of educations—in fact, we went to school every day—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’VE been to a day-school, too,’ said Alice; ‘you needn’t be so proud as all that.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘With extras?’ asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes,’ said Alice, ‘we learned French and music.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And washing?’ said the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Certainly not!’ said Alice indignantly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Ah! then yours wasn’t a really good school,’ said the Mock Turtle in a tone of great relief.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Now at OURS they had at the end of the bill, “French, music, AND WASHING—extra.”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You couldn’t have wanted it much,’ said Alice; ‘living at the bottom of the sea.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I couldn’t afford to learn it.’ said the Mock Turtle with a sigh.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I only took the regular course.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What was that?’ inquired Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Reeling and Writhing, of course, to begin with,’ the Mock Turtle replied; ‘and then the different branches of Arithmetic—Ambition, Distraction, Uglification, and Derision.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I never heard of “Uglification,”’ Alice ventured to say.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What is it?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Never heard of uglifying!’ it exclaimed.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You know what to beautify is, I suppose?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes,’ said Alice doubtfully: ‘it means—to—make—anything—prettier.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, then,’ the Gryphon went on, ‘if you don’t know what to uglify is, you ARE a simpleton.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said ‘What else had you to learn?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, there was Mystery,’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: the Mock Turtle replied, counting off the subjects on his flappers, ‘—Mystery, ancient and modern, with Seaography: then Drawling—the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel, that used to come once a week: HE taught us Drawling, Stretching, and Fainting in Coils.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What was THAT like?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, I can’t show it you myself,’ the Mock Turtle said: ‘I’m too stiff.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And the Gryphon never learnt it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Hadn’t time,’ said the Gryphon: ‘I went to the Classics master, though.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He was an old crab, HE was.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I never went to him,’ the Mock Turtle said with a sigh: ‘he taught Laughing and Grief, they used to say.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘So he did, so he did,’ said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And how many hours a day did you do lessons?’ said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Ten hours the first day,’ said the Mock Turtle: ‘nine the next, and so on.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What a curious plan!’ exclaimed Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s the reason they’re called lessons,’ the Gryphon remarked: ‘because they lessen from day to day.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then the eleventh day must have been a holiday?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course it was,’ said the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And how did you manage on the twelfth?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice went on eagerly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s enough about lessons,’ the Gryphon interrupted in a very decided tone: ‘tell her something about the games now.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter X. The Lobster Quadrille
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Same as if he had a bone in his throat,’ said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You may not have lived much under the sea—’ [‘I haven’t,’ said Alice)—‘ and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—’ (Alice began to say ‘I once tasted—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: but checked herself hastily, and said ‘No, never’) ‘—so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a Lobster Quadrille is!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, indeed,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What sort of a dance is it?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why,’ said the Gryphon, ‘you first form into a line along the sea-shore—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Two lines!’ cried the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on; then, when you’ve cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘THAT generally takes some time,’ interrupted the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—you advance twice—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Each with a lobster as a partner!’ cried the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course,’ the Mock Turtle said: ‘advance twice, set to partners—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—change lobsters, and retire in same order,’ continued the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then, you know,’ the Mock Turtle went on, ‘you throw the—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The lobsters!’ shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—as far out to sea as you can—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Swim after them!’ screamed the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Turn a somersault in the sea!’ cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Change lobsters again!’ yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Back to land again, and that’s all the first figure,’ said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It must be a very pretty dance,’ said Alice timidly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Would you like to see a little of it?’ said the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Very much indeed,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come, let’s try the first figure!’ said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘We can do without lobsters, you know.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Which shall sing?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, YOU sing,’ said the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve forgotten the words.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘“Will you walk a little faster?” said a whiting to a snail.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “There’s a porpoise close behind us, and he’s treading on my tail.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They are waiting on the shingle—will you come and join the dance?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
“You can really have no notion how delightful it will be
When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea!”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
But the snail replied “Too far, too far!” and gave a look askance—
Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘“What matters it how far we go?” his scaly friend replied.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “There is another shore, you know, upon the other side.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
The further off from England the nearer is to France—
Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, will you join the dance?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Will you, won’t you, will you, won’t you, won’t you join the dance?”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Thank you, it’s a very interesting dance to watch,’ said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last: ‘and I do so like that curious song about the whiting!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, as to the whiting,’ said the Mock Turtle, ‘they—you’ve seen them, of course?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes,’ said Alice, ‘I’ve often seen them at dinn—’ she checked herself hastily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I don’t know where Dinn may be,’ said the Mock Turtle, ‘but if you’ve seen them so often, of course you know what they’re like.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I believe so,’ Alice replied thoughtfully.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They have their tails in their mouths—and they’re all over crumbs.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’re wrong about the crumbs,’ said the Mock Turtle: ‘crumbs would all wash off in the sea.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But they HAVE their tails in their mouths; and the reason is—’ here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.—‘
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Tell her about the reason and all that,’ he said to the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The reason is,’ said the Gryphon, ‘that they WOULD go with the lobsters to the dance.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So they got thrown out to sea.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So they had to fall a long way.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So they got their tails fast in their mouths.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So they couldn’t get them out again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: That’s all.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Thank you,’ said Alice, ‘it’s very interesting.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I never knew so much about a whiting before.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I can tell you more than that, if you like,’ said the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Do you know why it’s called a whiting?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I never thought about it,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘IT DOES THE BOOTS AND SHOES.’ the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice was thoroughly puzzled.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Does the boots and shoes!’ she repeated in a wondering tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why, what are YOUR shoes done with?’ said the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I mean, what makes them so shiny?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They’re done with blacking, I believe.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Boots and shoes under the sea,’ the Gryphon went on in a deep voice, ‘are done with a whiting.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Now you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And what are they made of?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Soles and eels, of course,’ the Gryphon replied rather impatiently: ‘any shrimp could have told you that.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If I’d been the whiting,’ said Alice, whose thoughts were still running on the song, ‘I’d have said to the porpoise, “Keep back, please: we don’t want YOU with us!”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They were obliged to have him with them,’ the Mock Turtle said: ‘no wise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Wouldn’t it really?’ said Alice in a tone of great surprise.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course not,’ said the Mock Turtle: ‘why, if a fish came to ME, and told me he was going a journey, I should say “With what porpoise?”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Don’t you mean “purpose”?’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I mean what I say,’ the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And the Gryphon added ‘Come, let’s hear some of YOUR adventures.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I could tell you my adventures—beginning from this morning,’ said Alice a little timidly: ‘but it’s no use going back to yesterday, because I was a different person then.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Explain all that,’ said the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, no!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The adventures first,’ said the Gryphon in an impatient tone: ‘explanations take such a dreadful time.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so VERY wide, but she gained courage as she went on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating ‘YOU ARE OLD, FATHER WILLIAM,’ to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said ‘That’s very curious.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s all about as curious as it can be,’ said the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It all came different!’ the Mock Turtle repeated thoughtfully.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I should like to hear her try and repeat something now.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Tell her to begin.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Stand up and repeat “‘TIS THE VOICE OF THE SLUGGARD,”’ said the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How the creatures order one about, and make one repeat lessons!’ thought Alice; ‘I might as well be at school at once.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘’Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare,
“You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair.”
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose
Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark,
And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark,
But, when the tide rises and sharks are around,
His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s different from what I used to say when I was a child,’ said the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, I never heard it before,’ said the Mock Turtle; ‘but it sounds uncommon nonsense.’
