tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice said nothing; she had sat down with her face in her hands, wondering if anything would EVER happen in a natural way again.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I should like to have it explained,’ said the Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘She can’t explain it,’ said the Gryphon hastily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Go on with the next verse.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But about his toes?’ the Mock Turtle persisted.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘How COULD he turn them out with his nose, you know?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s the first position in dancing.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Go on with the next verse,’ the Gryphon repeated impatiently: ‘it begins “I passed by his garden.”’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye,
How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat,
While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon,
Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon:
While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl,
And concluded the banquet—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What IS the use of repeating all that stuff,’ the Mock Turtle interrupted, ‘if you don’t explain it as you go on?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It’s by far the most confusing thing I ever heard!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes, I think you’d better leave off,’ said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Shall we try another figure of the Lobster Quadrille?’ the Gryphon went on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,’ Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, ‘Hm!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: No accounting for tastes!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Sing her “Turtle Soup,” will you, old fellow?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘Beautiful Soup, so rich and green,
Waiting in a hot tureen!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Who for such dainties would not stoop?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
  Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Beautiful Soup!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
Who cares for fish,
   Game, or any other dish?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
Who would not give all else for two
Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Beau—ootiful Soo—oop!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
  Beautiful, beauti—FUL SOUP!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Chorus again!’ cried the Gryphon, and the Mock Turtle had just begun to repeat it, when a cry of ‘The trial’s beginning!’ was heard in the distance.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come on!’ cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What trial is it?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered ‘Come on!’ and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘Soo—oop of the e—e—evening,
  Beautiful, beautiful Soup!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter XI. Who Stole the Tarts?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them—all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them—‘ I wish they’d get the trial done,’ she thought, ‘and hand round the refreshments!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s the judge,’ she said to herself, ‘because of his great wig.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘And that’s the jury-box,’ thought Alice, ‘and those twelve creatures,’ (she was obliged to say ‘creatures,’ you see, because some of them were animals, and some were birds,) ‘I suppose they are the jurors.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: However, ‘jury-men’ would have done just as well.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What are they doing?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice whispered to the Gryphon.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They can’t have anything to put down yet, before the trial’s begun.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘They’re putting down their names,’ the Gryphon whispered in reply, ‘for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Stupid things!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out, ‘Silence in the court!’ and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down ‘stupid things!’ on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn’t know how to spell ‘stupid,’ and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘A nice muddle their slates’ll be in before the trial’s over!’ thought Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This of course, Alice could not stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Herald, read the accusation!’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts,
   All on a summer day:
 The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts,
   And took them quite away!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Consider your verdict,’ the King said to the jury.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Not yet, not yet!’ the Rabbit hastily interrupted.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There’s a great deal to come before that!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Call the first witness,’ said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out, ‘First witness!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The first witness was the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I beg pardon, your Majesty,’ he began, ‘for bringing these in: but I hadn’t quite finished my tea when I was sent for.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You ought to have finished,’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘When did you begin?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Fourteenth of March, I think it was,’ he said.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Fifteenth,’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Sixteenth,’ added the Dormouse.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Write that down,’ the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Take off your hat,’ the King said to the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It isn’t mine,’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Stolen!’ the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I keep them to sell,’ the Hatter added as an explanation; ‘I’ve none of my own.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: I’m a hatter.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Give your evidence,’ said the King; ‘and don’t be nervous, or I’ll have you executed on the spot.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I wish you wouldn’t squeeze so.’ said the Dormouse, who was sitting next to her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I can hardly breathe.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I can’t help it,’ said Alice very meekly: ‘I’m growing.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’ve no right to grow here,’ said the Dormouse.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Don’t talk nonsense,’ said Alice more boldly: ‘you know you’re growing too.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Yes, but I grow at a reasonable pace,’ said the Dormouse: ‘not in that ridiculous fashion.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court, ‘Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Give your evidence,’ the King repeated angrily, ‘or I’ll have you executed, whether you’re nervous or not.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m a poor man, your Majesty,’ the Hatter began, in a trembling voice, ‘—and I hadn’t begun my tea—not above a week or so—and what with the bread-and-butter getting so thin—and the twinkling of the tea—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The twinkling of the what?’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It began with the tea,’ the Hatter replied.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Of course twinkling begins with a T!’ said the King sharply.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Do you take me for a dunce?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Go on!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m a poor man,’ the Hatter went on, ‘and most things twinkled after that—only the March Hare said—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I didn’t!’ the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You did!’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I deny it!’ said the March Hare.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘He denies it,’ said the King: ‘leave out that part.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said—’ the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘After that,’ continued the Hatter, ‘I cut some more bread-and-butter—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But what did the Dormouse say?’ one of the jury asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That I can’t remember,’ said the Hatter.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You MUST remember,’ remarked the King, ‘or I’ll have you executed.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m a poor man, your Majesty,’ he began.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’re a very poor speaker,’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’m glad I’ve seen that done,’ thought Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’ve so often read in the newspapers, at the end of trials, “There was some attempts at applause, which was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court,” and I never understood what it meant till now.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If that’s all you know about it, you may stand down,’ continued the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I can’t go no lower,’ said the Hatter: ‘I’m on the floor, as it is.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then you may SIT down,’ the King replied.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Come, that finished the guinea-pigs!’ thought Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Now we shall get on better.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’d rather finish my tea,’ said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You may go,’ said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘—and just take his head off outside,’ the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Call the next witness!’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The next witness was the Duchess’s cook.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Give your evidence,’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Shan’t,’ said the cook.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, ‘Your Majesty must cross-examine THIS witness.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, if I must, I must,’ the King said, with a melancholy air, and, after folding his arms and frowning at the cook till his eyes were nearly out of sight, he said in a deep voice, ‘What are tarts made of?’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Pepper, mostly,’ said the cook.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Treacle,’ said a sleepy voice behind her.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Collar that Dormouse,’ the Queen shrieked out.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Behead that Dormouse!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Turn that Dormouse out of court!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Suppress him!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Pinch him!
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Off with his whiskers!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Never mind!’ said the King, with an air of great relief.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Call the next witness.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And he added in an undertone to the Queen, ‘Really, my dear, YOU must cross-examine the next witness.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: It quite makes my forehead ache!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like, ‘—for they haven’t got much evidence YET,’ she said to herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name ‘Alice!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
#AliceInWonderland
Chapter XII. Alice’s Evidence
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Here!’ cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, I BEG your pardon!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The trial cannot proceed,’ said the King in a very grave voice, ‘until all the jurymen are back in their proper places—ALL,’ he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said do.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: She soon got it out again, and put it right; ‘not that it signifies much,’ she said to herself; ‘I should think it would be QUITE as much use in the trial one way up as the other.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What do you know about this business?’ the King said to Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nothing,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nothing WHATEVER?’ persisted the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nothing whatever,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s very important,’ the King said, turning to the jury.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted: ‘UNimportant, your Majesty means, of course,’ he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘UNimportant, of course, I meant,’ the King hastily said, and went on to himself in an undertone,
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘important—unimportant—unimportant—important—’ as if he were trying which word sounded best.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Some of the jury wrote it down ‘important,’ and some ‘unimportant.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; ‘but it doesn’t matter a bit,’ she thought to herself.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out ‘Silence!’ and read out from his book, ‘Rule Forty-two.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ALL PERSONS MORE THAN A MILE HIGH TO LEAVE THE COURT.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Everybody looked at Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I’M not a mile high,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You are,’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nearly two miles high,’ added the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Well, I shan’t go, at any rate,’ said Alice: ‘besides, that’s not a regular rule: you invented it just now.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s the oldest rule in the book,’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then it ought to be Number One,’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Consider your verdict,’ he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘There’s more evidence to come yet, please your Majesty,’ said the White Rabbit, jumping up in a great hurry; ‘this paper has just been picked up.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘What’s in it?’ said the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I haven’t opened it yet,’ said the White Rabbit, ‘but it seems to be a letter, written by the prisoner to—to somebody.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It must have been that,’ said the King, ‘unless it was written to nobody, which isn’t usual, you know.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Who is it directed to?’ said one of the jurymen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It isn’t directed at all,’ said the White Rabbit; ‘in fact, there’s nothing written on the OUTSIDE.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: He unfolded the paper as he spoke, and added ‘It isn’t a letter, after all: it’s a set of verses.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Are they in the prisoner’s handwriting?’ asked another of the jurymen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, they’re not,’ said the White Rabbit, ‘and that’s the queerest thing about it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (The jury all looked puzzled.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘He must have imitated somebody else’s hand,’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (The jury all brightened up again.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Please your Majesty,’ said the Knave, ‘I didn’t write it, and they can’t prove I did: there’s no name signed at the end.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If you didn’t sign it,’ said the King, ‘that only makes the matter worse.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: You MUST have meant some mischief, or else you’d have signed your name like an honest man.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That PROVES his guilt,’ said the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It proves nothing of the sort!’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why, you don’t even know what they’re about!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Read them,’ said the King.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The White Rabbit put on his spectacles.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Where shall I begin, please your Majesty?’ he asked.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Begin at the beginning,’ the King said gravely, ‘and go on till you come to the end: then stop.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: These were the verses the White Rabbit read:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
‘They told me you had been to her,
 And mentioned me to him:
She gave me a good character,
 But said I could not swim.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
He sent them word I had not gone
 (We know it to be true):
If she should push the matter on,
 What would become of you?
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
I gave her one, they gave him two,
 You gave us three or more;
They all returned from him to you,
 Though they were mine before.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
If I or she should chance to be
 Involved in this affair,
He trusts to you to set them free,
 Exactly as we were.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
My notion was that you had been
 (Before she had this fit)
An obstacle that came between
 Him, and ourselves, and it.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text:
Don’t let him know she liked them best,
 For this must ever be
A secret, kept from all the rest,
 Between yourself and me.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘That’s the most important piece of evidence we’ve heard yet,’ said the King, rubbing his hands; ‘so now let the jury—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If any one of them can explain it,’ said Alice, (she had grown so large in the last few minutes that she wasn’t a bit afraid of interrupting him,) ‘I’ll give him sixpence.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: _I_ don’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The jury all wrote down on their slates, ‘SHE doesn’t believe there’s an atom of meaning in it,’ but none of them attempted to explain the paper.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘If there’s no meaning in it,’ said the King, ‘that saves a world of trouble, you know, as we needn’t try to find any.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: And yet I don’t know,’ he went on, spreading out the verses on his knee, and looking at them with one eye; ‘I seem to see some meaning in them, after all.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: “—SAID I COULD NOT SWIM—” you can’t swim, can you?’ he added, turning to the Knave.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The Knave shook his head sadly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Do I look like it?’ he said.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (Which he certainly did NOT, being made entirely of cardboard.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘All right, so far,’ said the King, and he went on muttering over the verses to himself: ‘“WE KNOW IT TO BE TRUE—” that’s the jury, of course—“ I GAVE HER ONE, THEY GAVE HIM TWO—” why, that must be what he did with the tarts, you know—’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘But, it goes on “THEY ALL RETURNED FROM HIM TO YOU,”’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Why, there they are!’ said the King triumphantly, pointing to the tarts on the table.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Nothing can be clearer than THAT.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Then again—“ BEFORE SHE HAD THIS FIT—” you never had fits, my dear, I think?’ he said to the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Never!’ said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Then the words don’t FIT you,’ said the King, looking round the court with a smile.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: There was a dead silence.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘It’s a pun!’ the King added in an offended tone, and everybody laughed, ‘Let the jury consider their verdict,’ the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘No, no!’ said the Queen.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Sentence first—verdict afterwards.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Stuff and nonsense!’ said Alice loudly.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘The idea of having the sentence first!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Hold your tongue!’ said the Queen, turning purple.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘I won’t!’ said Alice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Off with her head!’ the Queen shouted at the top of her voice.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Nobody moved.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Who cares for you?’ said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.)
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘You’re nothing but a pack of cards!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Wake up, Alice dear!’ said her sister; ‘Why, what a long sleep you’ve had!’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: ‘Oh, I’ve had such a curious dream!’ said Alice, and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about;
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said, ‘It WAS a curious dream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it’s getting late.’
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that WOULD always get into her eyes—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister’s dream.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by—the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess’s knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard’s slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality—the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen’s shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy—and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard—
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle’s heavy sobs.
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make THEIR eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago:
tweets.author: alice

tweets.text: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.
tweets.author: alice
